newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico crude shipments to Japan continue in storm.
newsitem.headline: Mexico crude shipments to Japan continue in storm.

text.p: Petroleum shipments to Japan from Mexico's Pacific crude port Salina Cruz continue despite restricted activity at the port, officials said Tuesday.
Officials at the port said the restrictions only appertained to movements of small boats at the country's sole Pacific crude port adding that petroleum loading and shipments would continue as normal.
Salina Cruz was closed to movements of small boats, tourist and fishing vessels, as of 1000 local/1600 GMT Tuesday.

Winds reaching 35 knots (39 miles/65 km per hour) in the surrounding Gulf of Tehuantepec near Oaxaca state forced the partial closure, the Communications and Transport ministry said in its meteorological bulletin.

The small port exported an average 90,000 barrels per day of crude oil in the first six months of the year to Japan, according figures from state-owned oil and gas monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex).
Pemex confirmed Tuesday its three principal crude ports in the Gulf of Mexico remain shut.
Mexico's main petroleum shipping ports include: Pajaritos in Veracruz state, Dos Bocas in Tabasco state and Cayo Arcas in Campeche state.

Other ports in the state of Tamaulipas reopened, as a cold front afflicting the Gulf of Mexico blew away from the state and across the Yucatan peninusla southeast at 10 knots (11 miles/19 kilometers per hour), the ministry said.
But strong winds kept seven ports, including the three crude ports, closed in the states of Veracruz, Tabasco, Campeche and Yucatan, the government report said.
